ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Seemed more like a virtual lecture as there were not many opportunities for student engagement and it was also difficult to interject to ask questions during professor presentations.

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course takes on a lot of material, spanning German art from 1750-now so there are so many takeaways! The best thing about this course is that, because it covers so much material, everyone is able to direct their focus to whichever area of German art was most interesting to them. This was a great combination of art, philosophy, history, and even some science.

I gained a lot of proficiency in visual analysis, critical reading of history, and writing thanks to Prof. Phillipss well organized class and clear and helpful feedback. I also learned a lot not only about the German art and aesthetic traditions but also about the German history (literary, political, and economical) that contextualized them.
An overview of German Art from the eighteenth century to the present, which allowed me to reconsider and revisit topics I studied in the past.

This course gave me a solid background in German art and aesthetics, from early Germany until today. It also helped me to manage a large reading load, refine my writing and research abilities, and better articulate and share my ideas and observations in a small discussion format.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Because of the complex nature of many of the materials covered in this course, the long seminar style could be taxing. Personally, I think this course would have been better suited for a twice a week meeting style, as we could have covered more of the material that we had to skip over because of time restraints and spread out the reading load a bit.

This was a fantastic course and I have no suggestions for improvementit would have been really nice to get to see some of the relevant art in the Yale collections but for obvious pandemic reasons this was not possible. Nevertheless Prof. Phillips adapted to the virtual medium really well and structured her class in a way very harmonious with the material circumstances of the zoom medium.

Strength: extraordinary array of material and knowledge covered throughout the course
Weakness: there was no room left to engage collectively with the readings in depth, some aspects of German Art were described hastily
How it could be improved: more group discussions on the readings

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Laura was extremely kind to all of us when it came to deadlines and was always available for out-of-class meetings. She was very attentive to each of our ideas and contributions to discussion even though everything was conducted virtually. She provided a thorough and extensive list of readings and artworks that were easy to access from home.
The challenges of online education were overcome. The course felt as though it was in person.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class seemed to be the most accessible for those students who already had some background in German, German history, or German artit was a little daunting for someone to just jump into it. Though, if you have a distinct interest in any aspect of German art from 1750-now it is a great course to take to focus on that interest while also learning about how it came to be. I would recommend working with the professor to make sure you get when you want out of the course and don't feel overwhelmed by all of the other material.

I absolutely would recommend this course (or any course with Prof. Phillips) to another student. Her passion for the material is infectious; she is a great teacher and discussion facilitator; and her feedback was much more in depth and helpful than I have often received in other seminars.
Great opportunity to become familiar with the trajectory of German art from the eighteenth century to the present in a concise and clear way.
I would recommend this course to another student! The readings were extremely interesting and the small discussion format kept me engaged throughout.

extras.title:
HSAR 411 01
        Art and Aesthetics in Germany
